constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: CONARA Name: St Andrews Square Conservation Area
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Erection of two self contained units (1 x 2 bed and 1 x 3 bed) following the demolition of existing garages
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from the date of this decision.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990. (As amended)

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a) materials for all external finishes and window frames (including their manufacturer's specification, dimensions, colour and texture).Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to commencement of any development on site, a Construction Management Plan detailing the following:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Signing system for works traffic.(d) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(e) Means of enclosure of the site.(f) Wheel washing equipment.(g) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(h) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.shall be submitted to the planning authority for written agreement. The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the construction management plan, which shall be maintained throughout the entire construction period.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a) refuse storage facilities in accordance with the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, 2013 (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained:(a) boundary treatment, including walls, fences and gates (including their manufacturer's specification, colour and texture).Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4. Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide. Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason: In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details. Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: In order to prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until details of secure cycle parking facilities (providing a total of 4 cycle spaces) for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The levels of buildings, roads, parking areas and pathways within the site shall only be in accordance with details which shall have previously been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development is commenced.Reason: To ensure that the appearance and functioning of the development is satisfactory and to safeguard the amenities of adjoining occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012 and comply with Supplementary Planning Document 'Access for All' (July 2005).

Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, the two proposed balconies/terraces hereby approved to the south-west elevation shall not be used for amenity purposes until a privacy screen has been affixed around the entirety of the balcony/terrace to a height of 1.7m as measured from the floor level of the balcony/terrace. Aside from essential fixings, the screen(s) shall be constructed entirely of, and retained in, obscured-glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof and must be replaced in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.          Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works a hard and soft landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented prior to occupation and the tree planting/ landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans additional detailed drawings at Scale 1:5/1:10 of the window reveals, door reveals, overhangs, rainwater goods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works and the development shall then be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: In order to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows in relation to Unit 1 at first floor level and located in the north-west (flank) elevation shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The roof of the proposed development hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey end-terrace dwellinghouse located on Cranborne Avenue. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ConsultationsSix neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development;The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,The impact of the development on highways. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a wraparound single storey extension at the front, side and rear of the property. The proposed rear extension extends 4 metres in depth beyond the existing rear wall of the dwellinghouse, above the recommended 3-3.5 metres as stated in the Residential Design SPD 2013. However, it would not have an unacceptable impact on the dwellinghouse in terms of character and appearance, as it appears subordinate and proportionate to the dwellinghouse. Similarly, the proposed side extension is largely acceptable in relation to the requirements of the Residential Design SPD. Officers note however the proposed front extension, to facilitate a porch. The porch would not reflect the character of the main house, and appears like an obvious addition, largely due to the proposed repositioning of the entranceway to the dwellinghouse, through the creation of the porch and its connection to the side extension. Furthermore, the proposed roof of the porch does not reflect the roof style of the original dwellinghouse, and does not respect the symmetry of the adjoining property. As such, the proposed front extension would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse and streetscene. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal property to consider in relation to amenity is No. 46 Cranborne Avenue. This neighbouring property has an existing single storey rear extension. As such it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officers Comments: Whilst the application proposes the construction of a single storey extension at the front of the dwellinghouse, it would not impact the current parking provision. London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. Given that the proposal would include the loss of access to the rear garden, and that no details have been given to indicate that there would be secure onsite cycle storage, Officers consider it appropriate to impose a condition for the applicant to provide details of secure cycle storage prior to the occupation of the proposed development, if the application was approved.In conclusion, the proposed development would be contradictory with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Condition 16 (Biodiversity) - The RBK Biodiversity Officer has reviewed the information submitted and is satisfied this can now be approved.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above are agreed and that Condition 16 (Biodiversity) of planning permission 20/02235/CREG3 is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey end-terrace dwellinghouse located on Cranborne Avenue. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ConsultationsSix neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development.The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on highways. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a wraparound single storey extension at the front, side and rear of the property. The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house which shows an original outrigger. The existing rear toilet extension is not part of the original footprint. The proposed extension would therefore extend beyond the side elevation of the original footprint and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) & (ja) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey side and rear extensions, including new front bay window and alterations to fenestrationConsultationNine neighbouring properties have been notified and one objection has been received raising the following concerns:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings;- Inappropriate design/layout; and,- Noise.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and sustainable travel.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note a similar extension has been granted permission at neighbouring property, No. 32 Bearfield Road (20/02307/HOU dated 12.11.2020) which is currently being built. In this case, it is considered that the proposed bay window would unbalance the pair of semi detached dwellings, of which this site forms part, but it is recognised that there are examples along Bearfield Road of similar features e.g. at No. 40, so this would not be considered to cause harm to the street scene. The comments made in the representations about the individual character of the properties are noted, however, Officers consider that the alterations to the front (bay window), whilst not a reinstatement, would nonetheless be respectful to the style of the host property and of the wider area and as such would be acceptable in this instance. Officers acknowledge that the proposed side extension has been set back from the front elevation in compliance with policy guidance 35 of the Residential Design SPD 2013 so as not to create a terracing effect. The proposed single storey rear extension would not be readily visible from the street scene, and whilst not strictly in accordance with the SPD would nonetheless be acceptable in terms of impact on character and appearance. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The principal properties to be considered in relation to neighbouring amenity are the neighbouring properties No. 28 and No. 32 Bearfield Road. The proposed rear extension would extend approximately 6 m along the shared boundary with No. 32 to align with the permitted rear extension currently in construction and would be approximately 2.5 m from the rear wall of existing outrigger adjoining No. 28.  It would extend approximately 350 mm past the existing extension at No. 28 and has been designed to meet the BRE guidance. Due to the existing situation the proposed side and rear extensions would not adversely affect the amenity of either neighbour.  It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. The proposed extensions would not generate noise above and beyond the existing residential use.Car ParkingPolicy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety.  Policy DM10 supports this stance. Officer Comment:  The proposal would not affect the existing car parking facilities.Sustainable TravelPolicy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3, ensuring that a minimum of two short-stay and two long-stay cycle parking spaces are provided. Officer Comment: Access to the rear of the property would be lost should permission be granted. Further details on cycle parking would be required and if permitted, a condition securing this information would be applied.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Condition 13 (Sustainability) - Officers have reviewed the infomation submitted and are satisfied that it has been demonstrated that a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations in relation to CO2 reductions and an internal water usage rate of 105 l/p/day has been achieved and this condition can now be approved.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.4 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 neutral representation has been received relating to inappropriate design/layout. The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.RBK Transport Officer - No highway safety concerns however it would breach RBK Crossover Policy and result in the removal of the grass verge beyond the maximum permitted depth. A separate crossover application would not likely be successful for these above reasons. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment:Officers note that uniformed appearance of the grass verges along Oakdene Drive. Given the proposed increased width of the dropped kerb, over what is considered appropriate by the RBK Crossover Policy, it would result in the prominent reduction of the grass verge to the front of the dwelling. As such, officers consider that the proposed development would detract from the appearance and character of the surrounding area. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the nature of the proposal officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would widen the existing dropped kerb to a width of 4m measured from the back of the footway and a total of 5m from the public highway. While this measurement would be in excess of the the recommendations set out in the RBK Crossover Policy officers consider that it would not present any material harm to car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received relating to loss of light/sunlight and excessive height or bulk of building. The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed single storey rear extension would not adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of height and depth, and as such would appear a dominant addition to the host property which would detract from the appearance of the immediate surrounding area.While the proposed two storey side extension would not set back appropriately from the front elevation at first floor level, or set down from the ridge of the original roofslope, it would have a modest width, be set in appropriately from the shared boundary, and would propose a roof form that is in keeping with the original dwelling. As such, officers consider that the proposed development would appear an appropriate addition to the host property and would not appear an incongruous addition to the immediate surrounding area.The proposed front extension would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, and as such is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Officers note that the proposed rear dormer roof extension would partly extend over the first floor rear outrigger, however given that it would be set down from the ridge and would not span the width of the roofslope, officers consider it would appear a subordinate feature to the original dwelling, and would not detract from the appearance of the immediate vicinity.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the height, depth and siting of the proposed single storey rear extension, it would not pass the 45-degree test in relation to the closest habitable window of adjoining property No. 33 Alric Avenue, and as such officers consider the proposed extension would unduly comprise the amenities of No.33 Alric Avenue, by reason of loss of light/sunlight and overbearing appearance.However given the separation distance between the proposed single storey rear extension and neighbouring property No. 49 Alric Avenue, officers consider the proposed extension would not adversely affect the amenities of No. 49 Alric Avenue, by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light/sunlight or loss of privacy. Further, given the separation distance of the two storey side extension, front extension and roof dormer from the neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light/sunlight.Officers note that a window is proposed to the side elevation at first floor level, and while it would replace a window of similar size, given that it would extend closer to the shared boundary, to mitigate against any loss of privacy officers consider it appropriate to impose a condition in the event of an approval, to ensure the window is obscure glazed and non-opening at 1.7m above finished floor levels. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: While the proposal would demolish the existing garage, given that the internal dimensions of the existing garage would not conform to modern internal dimensions as recommended by the Sustainable Transport SPD, officers consider that the proposal would not result in the loss of on-site parking. Further, while the proposed development would construct an integral garage, officers note that the internal dimensions of the garage would also not comply with the parameters set out in the Sustainable Transport SPD and therefore could not safely accommodate a car or constitute additional off-street car parking provision.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

Site The application site is a two-storey end of terrace dwellinghouse located on Amberwood Rise. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.ConsultationsEight neighbouring properties were notified - 2 representations were received. One representation is in support of this application - no commentary was provided. The following comments were included in the other representation: "If this building project goes forward, it could present a golden opportunity to help local swifts through including artificial nest sites, ie. swift bricks or boxes, into the new construction. For this reason, it is requested that reference is made to this representation in the decision notification advisory section, and/or in the Officer's report."ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development; and, The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Note: The application includes the erection of a part single, double-storey side extension. It is stated in Policy Guidance 36 (Two-storey Side and First Floor Side Extensions) of the Residential Design SPD, that two-storey and first floor side extensions should be designed to be in harmony with the appearance and character of the area. The extension should remain subordinate to the original house and the roof of the extension should reflect and relate well to the main house and its roof. semi-detached or end of Terrace Properties proposed side extensions should also not exceed 50% of the width of the original house. The ridge of the roof of the proposed double-storey side extension, would not be set down in relation to that of the original dwellinghouse and the width of the side extension, would exceed 50% of the width of the original house. The proposal would introduce a double-storey side extension, which would visually protrude from the existing side elevation of the dwellinghouse and this would be clearly viewed from the streetscene. This would be an incongruous addition to the application site and has not been designed to be in harmony with the appearance and character of the area. Given the above, officers consider that the proposed double-storey side extension would be unacceptable, contrary to Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013). Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officers Note: The principal properties to be considered in relation to amenity are Nos.7 and 11 Amberwood Rise. No.9 Amberwood Rise has an existing single storey rear extension. The proposed additional rear extension would project 6.0 metres to the rear of the proposed two storey side addition and it would not adhere to the parameters set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth. Officers consider that the proposal would conflict with policy guidance 8 of the Residential Design SPD, 2013. Given that the rear extension would almost abut with the shared boundary with the adjoining property at No.11 Amberwood Rise and it would extend further in depth than is recommended, officers consider that the proposed development would cause an unacceptable loss of daylight, increase in the sense of enclosure to and loss of outlook to this adjoining property. The additional rear extension would abut with the shared boundary with the adjoining property at No.7 Amberwood Rise. Officers consider that the proposed development would cause an unacceptable increase in the sense of enclosure to and loss of outlook to the  adjoining property at No.7 Amberwood Rise. In conclusion, by reason of its height, bulk and massing the proposed two storey side extension would appear an incongruous addition to the original dwelling and would not respect the prevailing pattern of development or roofscape within the immediate streetscene. The proposed additional single storey rear extension, would also adversely impact the amenities of the neighbouring properties at are Nos.7 and 11 Amberwood Rise, by reason of an unacceptable loss of daylight, increase in the sense of enclosure and  loss of outlook to these  adjoining properties. The proposal is therefore contrary to policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
All drawings that have "DRAFT" on them are unnaceptable and must be re-submitted

Erection of roof extension with rear/ side dormer and rear Juliet balcony and installation of 2 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Internal alterations and associated rear landscaping.''

As part of the Council's Local List of Validation requirements this application needs to be accompanied by a supporting 'Heritage Statement'.  A copy of the Royal Borough of Kingston's information requirements and guidance on what the statement should contain are available on our website at www.kingston.gov.uk/planning.
